body_content.explanation: to put someone at risk for a second, third, etc. time from something harmful or unpleasant:
examples: There are better ways of overcoming a psychological injury than re-exposing the victim to his trauma.
The dog was placed in a nonallergenic environment for 14 days, then reexposed to its normal environment.

body_content.explanation: to remove what is covering something for a second, third, etc. time so that it can be seen:
examples: We must carefully weigh the risks of worsening the pollution by re-exposing the buried coal tar.
She made a photo that never happened by re-exposing the film to take a picture of two people at separate times.
